Key Arguments: The legislation will infringe on freedom of speech by granting ACMA new powers to determine what constitutes misinformation and disinformation.
There is concern over who decides what is misinformation or disinformation, as past instances have shown that what is initially labeled as 'fake news' can later be proven true.
The criteria for targeting misinformation are subjective and open to interpretation, including content deemed harmful to various societal aspects.
The legislation's broad scope could affect a wide range of internet platforms, likened to a 'Ministry of Truth'.
Notable Quotes: The federal government has declared that it will trample over freedom of speech by giving a government agency (ACMA) new powers to combat what it deems as ‘misinformation’ and ‘disinformation’ online.

The proposed law will cover social media platforms, search engines, news aggregators, web forums, video platforms like YouTube and podcasting platforms. Just about everything on the internet is in the firing line of this new Australian 'Ministry of Truth'!
